Matching algorithm used to integrate the: Natural Language Processing (NLP) identifies product co-mentions in public forums and reviews. Product SKUs are then matched to competitor bundle pages and marketplace 'Frequently Bought Together' sections using a combination of fuzzy string matching and product attribute normalization (e.g., '65-inch' vs '65"'). A synergy score is calculated based on the frequency and sentiment of these co-mentions.
Story:
We were approached by a regional consumer electronics retailer facing a classic margin squeeze. Their core product sales—televisions, laptops—were steady, but they were losing the battle on profitability. Their big-box competitors were masters of the upsell, using aggressive product bundles to increase the average order value (AOV) and move high-margin accessories. Our client's strategy, by contrast, was archaic. Their marketing team would manually create bundles once a quarter based on last year's sales data. The result? Uninspired pairings like a new TV bundled with an old, overstocked soundbar, which customers ignored.

Our team at Iceberg Data proposed a radical shift: let the market dictate the bundles in real-time. The core idea was to stop guessing what customers wanted and start listening to what they were already buying and discussing online. Our mission was to build a 'Bundle Intelligence Feed' that would give them an unfair competitive advantage. We deployed a multi-pronged data collection strategy. First, our scrapers continuously monitored the product pages of their top three national competitors, specifically targeting their official bundle promotions. We extracted the component products, the bundle price, and the implied discount.

Second, we targeted the 'Frequently Bought Together' and 'Customers Also Bought' sections of major e-commerce marketplaces. This was a goldmine of organic purchasing behavior, revealing the natural product affinities that existed outside of any formal promotion. Third, and most powerfully, we used NLP models to parse discussions on specialized public tech forums. We wanted to know: when someone buys a new 'TV-OLED-65X-2024', what specific soundbar, wall mount, or 4K Blu-ray player are the enthusiasts on Reddit's r/hometheater recommending to go with it? This qualitative data provided the 'why' behind the purchasing trends.

The initial results were eye-opening. The client had been trying to bundle their flagship OLED TV with a mid-range soundbar from the same manufacturer. Our data showed this was a critical mistake. Online, customers and reviewers consistently paired that exact TV with a competitor's Dolby Atmos soundbar, the 'SOUNDBAR-ATMOS-714', citing superior audio quality. Furthermore, our marketplace data showed a high co-purchase velocity for a specific 'WALL-MOUNT-ULTRA-SLIM' that the client didn't even stock heavily. They were missing out on two high-margin attachment opportunities.

Armed with this data, which we delivered via a clean API output as shown in the example JSON, their team ran an A/B test. 'Bundle A' was their old, internally-devised package. 'Bundle B' was our data-driven recommendation: the OLED TV, the competitor's premium soundbar (which they decided to stock), and the ultra-slim wall mount. The results were staggering. Bundle B outsold Bundle A by a factor of four and lifted the AOV for those transactions by 22%.

We expanded this system across their entire catalog, from gaming PCs to kitchen appliances. They could now react within 48 hours to a competitor's new promotion or a surge in online discussion about a new 'must-have' accessory for a popular product. They stopped using discounts to get rid of old inventory and started creating value-driven packages that customers genuinely wanted. Within six months, their overall AOV had climbed by 18%, and their accessory attachment rate soared by 35%. They were no longer just selling a product; they were selling a complete, data-validated solution.
